thread.title: Rescue after scaffold collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland
thread.title_full: Rescue after scaffold collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland

title: Rescue after scaffold collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland
text:
Rescue after scaffold collapse at old Panmure Bridge, Auckland Last updated 12:13, February 21 2017 NZN VIDEO 
Dramatic rescue after scaffold collapse in Panmure, Auckland. 
A person was trapped against the Panmure Bridge in Auckland after scaffolding collapsed throwing up to seven people into the water on Tuesday. 
Fire Service shift manager Carlos Dempsey said it was unclear how many people had been in the water, but emergency services has rescued three from the water after the incident at 10am. 
One person was trapped in the scaffolding and was rescued by the fire service's high angle rescue team. 
A man was trapped by the fallen scaffolding, and was rescued by the fire service's high angle rescue team. 
They had used a turntable ladder appliance to reach the man, he said. 
He man seemed unfazed by the drama. 
He drummed his hands against the bridge as he waited for help, then he shook hands with his rescuers. CAT OWEN/FAIRFAX NZ 
A view of the collapsed scaffolding on Panmure Bridge. 
Witnesses told 1News the scaffolding collapse sounded "like a plane was landing". 
A local resident, who did not want to be named, said he heard a loud bang around the time the scaffolding collapsed. 
Scaffolding had been installed at the bridge for the past month, he said. 1 NEWS 
The collapse at the old Panmure Bridge left four people in the water. 
St John spokesman Mark Deoki said one patient in a moderate condition and two patients with minor injuries were taken to Middlemore Hospital. Ad Feedback 
Another patient was being assessed at A&E. 
Two ambulances and a specialist response team attended the collapse and a number of bystanders helped with the rescue effort. It was hard to determine exactly how the scaffolding collapsed, he said. CAT OWEN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Collapsed scaffolding in the lagoon beneath Panmure Bridge. 
The bridge remained open to traffic. 
It is understood the bridge was undergoing paint and concrete repairs. 
WorkSafe spokesman Chris Baylis said the organisation had been notified and were making initial inquiries. CAT OWEN/FAIRFAX NZ
